user.biography:
• Photographer
• Nat Geo Explorer
• Director
• Creator of Day to Night ™
• TED speaker

node.text: During our recent shoot In Iceland of the Fagradalshraun Volcano, I had a few moments to use my drone to capture the volcano from a different perspective, and in the process revealing the epic scale of the lava river that’s grown exponentially during the last few weeks . As soon as I flew close to the volcano, it began erupting... and as I began to fly away avoiding the heat and lava from the volcano, the massive lava field comes into perspective.  Click the IGTV icon to see the full video!

node.text: I am so fortunate to be a member of the TED Speaker community and was so honored when the team at TED asked me to participate in the 2020 TED Countdown global launch.  I was asked create a short visual and a poetic reflection using my photographs to illustrate climate change.  My hope is that this work will open people’s minds and allow them to reflect on how profound the issue of climate change really is.  Congratulations  to the Countdown team at TED for an incredibly successful launch.  I hope to continue to work with TED and all of the other activists in accelerating solutions to the climate crisis.

node.text: A big thanks to @nonstopnewyork for posting this piece on my Day to Night work!! During my recent exhibition @brycewolkowitz gallery I had the pleasure of sitting down with Carol Anne Riddell to discuss the origin of Day to Night and some of the amazing experiences I’ve had along the way.  Click the IGTV icon to see the full piece!! #nonstopnewyork #daytonight #brycewolkowitzgallery

node.text: A big thanks to @nonstopnewyork for posting this piece on my Day to Night work!! During my recent exhibition @brycewolkowitz gallery I had the pleasure of sitting down with Carol Anne Riddell to discuss the origin of Day to Night and some of the amazing experiences I’ve had along the way.  Click the IGTV icon to see the full piece!! #nonstopnewyork #brycewolkowitzgallery #daytonight

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Stephen Wilkes on September 08, 2021 tagging @brycewolkowitz. May be an image of nature and body of water.

node.text:
Lake Como, Italy 2015.  This image is from when I first started experimenting with my tapestry series.  I had just traveled from Venice where I was inspired by the tapestries I saw hanging in the Vatican Museum.  I loved the layering of imagery, narrative storytelling & color that appeared throughout the woven texture of the yarn.  Experimenting constantly I set out to try and create a similar effect with my camera.  Lake Como proved to be the perfect canvas for that exploration.

I hope you can join us tomorrow for the opening of my Tapestry series @brycewolkowitz gallery 505 West 24th Street, New York, NY!!
Opening reception is from 6:00-8:00pm.  This image along with many others will be on display until October 16th. Click the link in my bio for more information.  Hope to see everyone there!! #lakecomo #italy #tapestry #exploration #photography

Photo shared by Stephen Wilkes on September 07, 2021 tagging @brycewolkowitz.

node.text:
This tapestry was shot with my iPhone this past winter on Sherwood Island in Westport, CT. I love how the snow on top of the rock blends into the winter sky.  You can feel the texture of rock and snow throughout the entire picture. 

I hope you can visit this Thursday,  September 9th for the opening of my Tapestry series exhibition @brycewolkowitz gallery 505 West 24th Street New York, NY.  Opening reception is from 6:00-8:00pm.  This image along with many others in the Tapestry series will be on display through October 16th.  Click the link in my bio for more information.  Hope to see everyone there!! #shotoniphone #winter #tapestry #snow #westportct #sherwoodisland

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Stephen Wilkes on September 05, 2021 tagging @brycewolkowitz. May be art of outdoors.

node.text: A tapestry from my upcoming exhibition with @brycewolkowitz gallery.  I created  this tapestry of the iconic gondolas docked along the edge of the Grand Canal in my favorite city,  Venice, Italy in 2015.  This project has allowed for an entirely new way of seeing. I’m  looking forward to sharing these photographs and hope you can join us for the opening reception for “Tapestries” Thursday September 9th from 6-9pm at Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery. The exhibition will continue thru October 16th.  Click the link in my bio for more information.  Hope to see everyone there!! #venice #grandcanal #gondola  #tapestry #photography

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Stephen Wilkes on September 04, 2021 tagging @brycewolkowitz. May be an image of jacaranda, nature and tree.

node.text:
I created this tapestry during the early summer while on my daily walk in CT.  The summer flowers in CT were stunningly beautiful this past year, and the rhododendron were particularly spectacular.  I love seeing the subtle changes in the flowers’ colors. As it moves from shadow to sunlight, the tapestry optimally blends these different colors and natural elements together within a matter of seconds .

We hope you can join us next Thursday September 9th for the opening of my Tapestry series @brycewolkowitz gallery 505 West 24th Street, New York, NY .
Opening reception is from 6:00-8:00pm.  This image along with many others will be on display until October 16th.  Click the link in my bio for more information.  Hope to see everyone there!! #iphonography #shotoniphone #tapestry #flowers #exhibition

node.text:
We are thrilled to be opening my new Tapestry series @brycewolkowitz gallery on Thursday 9/9. This series is eight years in the making and is inspired by the great tapestries during the Renaissance. The photographs comprise cityscapes and the natural world all captured in camera over a 4-8 seconds period of time .  This image is from one of my favorite places on Block Island, RI.  I photographed textured water along a pond and then the dramatic field that it overlooks.  Tapestries are my exploration of trying to capture a feeling that I’m experiencing in all these places. 

This image and many others will be on display from September 9th to October 16th at Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery, 505 West 24th Street New York, NY.  The opening reception is September 9th from 6:00-8:00pm.  Click the link in my bio for more information.  I hope you all can join us!! #tapestry #texture #photography #nyc #exhibition

node.text: I created this tapestry while on a walk at Lake Mohegan in Fairfield, CT.  The juxtaposition of the spring greenery against the reflections on the water’s surface inspired thoughts of Monet.  Over the last 8 years I’ve been working on a series called “Tapestries” inspired by the great tapestries during the Renaissance. These photographs are made all in camera, multiple exposures & usually happen within 4-8 seconds. They are layered captures of unique moments in time.  I’m excited to share that this image will be featured in my upcoming fourth solo exhibition with Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery!  Opening reception is Thursday September 9th from 6-8pm at Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery, 505 West 24th Street, New York, NY.  See the link in my bio for details.  I hope you can all join us!! #tapestry #lakemohegan #fairfield #ct #nyc #exhibition #photography

node.text:
Over the last six months I’ve been sharing photographs from a project that is inspired by the great tapestries of the Renaissance.  Eight years ago, while in Italy, I visited the Vatican Museum and became fascinated by the extraordinary tapestries hanging from the walls.  I was inspired by the layering of imagery, narrative storytelling and color that appeared throughout the woven texture of the yarn.  I began to wonder if I could create a similar effect while photographing and started exploring the possibilities with my camera. 

I am excited to share this exploration, “Tapestries” with my fourth solo exhibition at Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery.  The photographs in this exhibition are created in camera, and are multiple exposures within four to eight seconds.  Comprised of abstract images, seasonal images & cityscapes, they are layered captures of unique moments in time.  The opening reception is Thursday, September 9th  at Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery , 505 West 24th Street, New York, NY from 6-8pm. The exhibition runs through October 16th.  Click the link in my bio for details.  I hope you all can join us!! #tapestry #duomo #venice #nyc #photography

node.text:
Bay St. Louis Mississippi… 
Hurricane Ida has made landfall on the 16th anniversary of the historically devastating Hurricane Katrina. As a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 150 mph. 

I have spent many years documenting the Gulf coast, and my heart goes out to the wonderful people of New Orleans and the Gulf Coast who are yet again in harms way of another massive storm.  This is a photograph I made in Bay St Louis , Mississippi just after Hurricane Katrina.  Please stay safe . #gulfcoast #stlouis #neworleans #weareone #photography

node.text:
I’ve always been inspired by the work and words of Alfred Stieglitz. 

“My cloud photographs are equivalents of my most profound life experiences, my basic philosophy of life.  All art is an equivalent of the artists most profound life experiences.” Alfred Stieglitz 

 #clouds #stieglitz #equivalents #photography

node.text: Number 18 in my tapestry series.  As I’ve continued to evolve this body of work, I’m beginning to bring in elements about climate and the pollution of our oceans.  Over the last 8 years I’ve been quietly working on a series called “Tapestries” inspired by the great tapestries during the Renaissance. These photographs are made all in camera, multiple exposures & usually happen within 4-8 seconds. They are layered captures of unique moments in time. #tapestry #climatechange  #oceans #photography #renaissance

node.text:
A photo from the archive in honor of global climbing day.  I took this photograph as part of an ad campaign to launch Etkar film for Kodak. We made this photograph by getting special permission to land two stunt climbers on top of the iconic totem pole in Monument Valley. They were dropped out of a helicopter onto a roughly 8ft wide sandstone top with a several hundred ft line of rope, which they used to rappel down .  The only other time that the totem pole was used for a commercial shoot was the filming of the Clint Eastwood’s film , “The Eiger Sanction”.
I shot this with a 28mm lens, which put me quite physically close to the totem pole.  If you look closely at the shadow of the totem pole in this photograph, you’ll see a small shadow towards the top, about a third of the way down….that’s me in the helicopter 🚁! #climbing #kodak #helicopter #monumentvalley
